metadata.case_name: Appellant Company v. Their Clerical Staff

facts.text: Appeal by special leave arises out of an industrial dispute between the appellant company and their clerical staff on the question of bonus for the year 1956.
Demand of the workmen was for bonus equivalent to 8 months total earnings of the year.
Company resisted demand on ground that there was an agreement between company and its labour employees whereby bonus for 1956 had been settled at 4-1/2 months basic wages.
General practice in awards in the matter of bonus had been to award lesser amounts to clerical employees than to labour.
Granting same rate of bonus to clerical and labour employees would encourage strife and discontent.
Tribunal held agreement as regards bonus for 1956 voluntarily entered into on behalf of workers and beneficial to them.
Tribunal awarded bonus at rate of 9/24ths of basic wages to clerical staff for year ending December 31, 1956, same scale as labour.
In written statement before Tribunal, company referred to another reference (I.T. 279 of 1957) claiming no gap between actual wage and living wage.
No independent statement on wage gap in present reference (I.T. 106 of 1955), no reference in award.
For year 1951, clerical staff and operatives in Burmah Shell, Caltex, Standard Vacuum Calcutta office got bonus at same rate of 3 months basic wages.
During pendency, agreements for 3-1/2 months wages for 1951.
In Burmah-Shell Co. v. Their Workmen before Industrial Tribunal Ernakulam, company counsel conceded not to press distinction in bonus.
Pay scale of clerical staff higher than labour staff.
Starting remuneration middle grade operatives Rs. 188.94, clerks Rs. 404.45 on Jan 1, 1958.
Tribunal conscious of wage difference, noted clerical from middle class with higher living standard, suffered from price rise.

legal_issues.text: Whether Tribunal erred in awarding bonus without recording conclusion as regards existence and extent of gap between actual wages and living wage.
Whether Tribunal erred in granting bonus to clerical staff at same rate as labour staff, or should have granted lower rate.

petitioner_arguments.text: Tribunal erred in awarding bonus without conclusion on gap between actual wages and living wage.
For many years practice in petroleum industry to give lower bonus to clerical than operatives.
Awarding same rate to clerical as labour would cause discontent among labour staff.
Pay scale of clerical higher, gap between living wage and actual wage less, so bonus at same rate wrong as bonus bridges gap.
Difference in average wage of clerical and operatives more than difference in their living wages (clerical living wage only 80 more).

court_reasoning.text: First contention on wage gap not raised seriously before Tribunal, no reference in award, not in special leave petition or statement of case, not open to urge.
No uniform practice of lower bonus to clerical; in some years same rate given, e.g., 1951 in Calcutta offices, Ernakulam concession.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Premise of uniform practice not established.

court_reasoning.text: Bonus based on contribution by labour to profits; contribution by workmen as a class, not sectional.
Not ordinarily fair to distinguish rates between classes absent overriding consideration; no inflexible rule but discretion of tribunal.
Tribunal considered middle class living standard of clerical, price rise suffering; conclusion reasonable.
No basis for assuming living wage clerical only 80 more than operatives; living wage components differ from fair wage.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cannot infer smaller gap from wages.

holdings.text: Appellant cannot urge contention on wage gap as not raised before Tribunal.
No substance in argument for lower bonus to clerical; award of same rate justified.
Payment of bonus based on contribution of all workmen as class; ordinarily no distinction in rates between classes absent overriding reason.
Tribunals have wide discretion in bonus rates; not to interfere unless arbitrary.

precedents_cited.case_name: Burmah-Shell Oil Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Discussed 1951 bonus same for clerical and operatives in Calcutta offices.
Company conceded no distinction in bonus rates.

precedents_cited.case_name: Burn Co., Calcutta v. Their Employees
precedents_cited.relevance: Profits result of all workmen; sectional bonus unfair, leads to disaffection.

precedents_cited.case_name: Karam Chand Thapar Bros. Workmen v. The Company
Baroda Borough Municipality v. Its Workmen
Standard Vacuum Refining Co., Ltd. v. Its Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Components of living wage differ from fair wage.

outcome.summary: The Court dismissed the appeal, upholding the Tribunal's award of bonus at 9/24ths of basic wages to clerical staff, same as labour staff, finding no merit in contentions raised.

key_quotes.text: "The entire profits of the company are the result of the labour of all the workmen and employees in all its units."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Principle that bonus based on collective contribution of all workmen.

key_quotes.text: "In the absence of some overriding consideration it would not be fair to make a distinction in the rate of bonus between different classes of workmen."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Holding on equal bonus rates ordinarily fair.

key_quotes.text: "The industrial tribunals must have very wide discretion in deciding matters like this and it is not for this Court to interfere with their exercise of discretion, unless it is plainly arbitrary."
key_quotes.speaker: court
